messages: 592418d171424c8cbfdcdf34eaf7f587 (03:10): Looks like 2.1 is from October, I'll go with that...
592418d171424c8cbfdcdf34eaf7f587 (03:14): I still hear horror stories on the mailing lists.
592418d171424c8cbfdcdf34eaf7f587 (03:14): When 3.0.1 comes out, I'll think more about that.
592418d171424c8cbfdcdf34eaf7f587 (03:15): Nobody's been able to explain to me how we suddenly jumped from 2.1 to 3.0 either.  I'm not sure what changed enough to warrant the major version bump.
592418d171424c8cbfdcdf34eaf7f587 (03:16): s/explain/explain in a way that stuck/
4eded2e2ccb0d854d6531d32be442eb5 (03:17): It was discussed in great lengths on the mailing lists.
7a0cf7e96de6600fd2a9a7a46abbfec1 (03:17): someone needs to do some benchmarking :)
592418d171424c8cbfdcdf34eaf7f587 (03:18): liamjfoy: Are you saying that 3.0 is fast?
4eded2e2ccb0d854d6531d32be442eb5 (03:18): ball: here's the digest of the reasoning http://mail-index.netbsd.org/tech-kern/2004/09/30/0020.html
592418d171424c8cbfdcdf34eaf7f587 (03:19): voidcast: the first paragraph that I read made sense.
592418d171424c8cbfdcdf34eaf7f587 (03:22): So 2.1 was stable enough that 3.0 was the next logical step?
11dcbf8105451bb7a15317b15a0e60f1 (03:22): ball: I've been running 3 since beta, and it's always run like a charm... running netbsd since 1.6... and 3 met my expectations.
592418d171424c8cbfdcdf34eaf7f587 (03:23): I have some 1.4 boot floppies somewhere :-)
592418d171424c8cbfdcdf34eaf7f587 (03:23): yukonbob: I'm half way through downloading 2.1 now.
592418d171424c8cbfdcdf34eaf7f587 (03:24): I should read the "What's new in 3.0" thing.
7a0cf7e96de6600fd2a9a7a46abbfec1 (03:27): Adadio for strings is a cool tune
592418d171424c8cbfdcdf34eaf7f587 (03:28): Looks like lots of yummy device drivers too.
11dcbf8105451bb7a15317b15a0e60f1 (03:30): if you upgrade from 2, make sure you do the etcupdate... you'll need the PAM configs to log in :)
592418d171424c8cbfdcdf34eaf7f587 (03:31): yukonbob: When I eventually move to 3.0, I'll probably just wipe one of my 1.6 machines and do a fresh install.
7db2871df8acdae30a67b88beabae832 (03:45): people ask too much question, and dont answer enough
334980e1e056773993bf52426a66cdc9 (03:47): is there a way to change the fs type of a drive without formatting?
7a0cf7e96de6600fd2a9a7a46abbfec1 (03:55): voidcast, yeah I emailed him about that;)
f1ac60ceaad69b9c4b9a8654560f1e53 (03:56): xSmurf: sure, but it won't be usefull
334980e1e056773993bf52426a66cdc9 (03:57): but, why wouldn't it? and how?
f1ac60ceaad69b9c4b9a8654560f1e53 (03:58): a filesystem isn't just a name
f1ac60ceaad69b9c4b9a8654560f1e53 (03:58): you can't just decide you UFS is now FAT32
334980e1e056773993bf52426a66cdc9 (03:58): I didn't mean just change i on the partition map
334980e1e056773993bf52426a66cdc9 (03:58): I meant while keeping the files intact
7db2871df8acdae30a67b88beabae832 (04:00): so.. your question is pretty paradoxal
334980e1e056773993bf52426a66cdc9 (04:01): true, but there is a way to repartion (expand, contract) a partition without losing data
7db2871df8acdae30a67b88beabae832 (04:02): but, as carneous said, not every FS can do that
7db2871df8acdae30a67b88beabae832 (04:04): I think you can resize UFS with growfs(8)
314b06e1f333b6d01763947e553c1451 (04:05): I asked someone to build that for me because I currently can't
8d102cab8535e4a2d9e4ef284cd63b16 (04:29): rpaulo: miredo should work on 3.99.21 right?
